Scott Kennedy wrote:
> Thanks.  My firewall seemed to be blocking images.  It's working now.
> 
> Now, at the risk of blocking images again, if I want to crawl only *pages* on the hosts in the seeds file, but to download any embedded images that are hosted on other sites.
> 
> For example, if I were to crawl www.cnn.com, I would want all the images from cdn.turner.com, but I wouldn't want to crawl any pages on cdn.turner.com (only www.cnn.com).

There's no neat, bright-line definition of 'pages' to use. For example, 
what if HTML on cnn.com pulls in, from other hosts, embedded Javascript 
or CSS required to render that HTML? Usually, people who want embedded 
images want these files too -- the pages look mangled without them -- so 
via the 'TransclusionDecideRule' in the standard scope, these are also 
retrieved.

How about embedded frames of HTML from another host? Are they part of 
the cnn.com 'page' or are they a separate 'page' on the other host?

Again, the defaults assume you want these, if they are embedded on your 
main host of interest, because otherwise you can't browse an accurate 
representation of the content on the main host. (Similarly, embedded 
images inside these frames are transitively included as well, even if 
they are on yet a third host.)

In general the defaults try to err on the side of collecting too much, 
because storage is cheap and a little extra unwanted material can be 
ignored in later indexing/viewing, but if a URI is not retrieved and 
then disappears from the web, it's gone forever.

> I was thinking about rejecting in a NotOnHostsDecideRule, but accepting if the content type matches "image/.*", but maybe there's a better way?

You don't even know the content-type of a URI until after it is fetched, 
so content-type can't help in the scoping rules. (It can be used to 
knock URIs out later -- such as early-aborting the fetch or skipping 
link-extraction or ARC-storage.)

For whatever unique definition of 'page' or desired inclusion/exclusion 
policy you have, there's sure to be a way to implement it. (If it goes 
beyond what's possible with the existing rules, you can even add your 
own in Beanshell or Java code.)

But, tinkering with the rules is likely to have surprising results, 
perhaps missing desired material, until you become experienced in 
crafting the rule choices and ordering. So I would recommend against it 
unless you've tried the default scope, seen exactly what it retrieved 
that you don't want, and developed a precise idea of how to exclude 
those URIs without collateral damage.
